poem:
Title: "Verses from Resistance Street"

In punkish rhythm's fiery feud,
Sings a tale, slightly crude.
Against the loudest foe - intolerance bold,
Music's fight, ages old.
A history of strife, every note imbued,
Within a budget, modestly pursued.
Lo-fi echoes of passion, rightly incensed,
For such a narrative, truth's defence,
Minor in part, but vast in heart,
A song against hate, an indispensable art.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "On Resistance Street review – punkish record of music’s long battle with racism There’s no better time than now for a documentary on popular music’s role in the fight against racism and fascism. And in true punk spirit, this lo-fi indie packs in a lot of history and righteous passion for not much budget – even if, to be brutally honest, its core narrative is a very minor part of that history, centred on a". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
